item.title: Woman unable to breathe through nose after Turkey teeth op
item.description: Leanne Abeyance's face is constantly infected after dental work done in Turkey.

item.title: Trust apologises for treating A&E patients in cafe
item.description: Using the cafe to treat patients "will not be allowed to happen again", the trust's boss says.

item.title: AI can forecast your future health – just like the weather
item.description: An artificial intelligence model can predict the risk of more than 1,000 diseases, a team of scientists say.

item.title: Don't scrap care plans for children with special educational needs, say MPs
item.description: Concerns grow over the government's plans to reform special needs education in England.

item.title: IT systems at major hospitals restored but disruption continues
item.description: The majority of planned surgery and out-patient hospital appointments in the Southern Trust are being cancelled for Thursday.

item.title: Thousands of opioid deaths missed off official figures
item.description: The error - affecting England and Wales - raises concerns about the impact on the government's approach to drug deaths.

item.title: Fourteen NHS trusts' maternity care to be investigated over 'failures'
item.description: Families impacted have criticised the review, calling it "not fit for purpose".

item.title: Gonorrhoea vaccines served up at Soho's G-A-Y Bar
item.description: A leading sexual health clinic is running the drop-in sessions at G-A-Y Bar to boost uptake.

item.title: What the NHS can learn from the European country that helped more people survive cancer
item.description: Denmark's survival rates record for certain cancers were poor compared to some other wealthy countries. Then it came up with a bold plan

item.title: Alzheimer's blood test could 'revolutionise' diagnosis
item.description: Scientists leading the trial at University College London believe the blood test could improve the accuracy of diagnosis of the disease to more than 90%.

item.title: Fertility clinics must stop unproven treatments, watchdog warns
item.description: The draft guidance advises against many popular but unproven fertility add-ons offered by clinics.

item.title: Best and worst-performing NHS Trusts in England named
item.description: Critics question the usability of new league tables meant to inform the public and let them exercise choice.

item.title: Deodorant firm sorry after 'itchy, burning armpits' claims
item.description: Mitchum said a change in the manufacturing process had affected some of its roll-on products after users complained of soreness.

item.title: Error leaves 55,000 diabetes patients needing new tests
item.description: Errors by diabetes analysis machines mean at least 55,000 people in England will need further hospital tests.

item.title: Disabled NHS medic told she's 'not a real doctor'
item.description: Disabled and neurodivergent doctors say the lack of reasonable adjustments is pushing some out.

item.title: 'My son's constipation wasn't taken seriously until he reached crisis point'
item.description: The number of children being admitted to hospital with constipation is at a 10-year high.

item.title: Energy drinks to be banned for under-16s in England
item.description: Health and Social Care Secretary Wes Streeting said he was acting on concerns for children's health.

item.title: Organ transplants for immortality: Might Xi and Putin be onto something?
item.description: The presidents of China and Russia were overheard discussing transplants as a way to prolong life.

item.title: Adults with learning disabilities die 20 years early, report finds
item.description: People with learning disabilities and autism die almost 20 years younger than the rest of the population.

item.title: Vaccination plea after baby's 'terrifying' measles
item.description: Eight areas in the North East and Cumbria have seen a slight or moderate increase in MMR jab rates.

item.title: AI stethoscope could detect major heart conditions in seconds
item.description: The new technology could be a "game-changer" resulting in patients being treated sooner, experts say.

item.title: Children to be offered chickenpox vaccine on NHS
item.description: All young children in England and Wales will be offered a free chickenpox vaccine by the NHS from January 2026.

item.title: Price of Mounjaro to be discounted in UK pharmacies
item.description: The rebate allays fears of a 170% price rise but patients are warned the cost of the drug will still jump.

item.title: Seven-week wait for some red flag cancer patients 'frustrating'
item.description: The target set by the Department of Health for patients red flagged for breast cancer to be assessed is 14 days.

item.title: Brain image doctor banned for assault and racism
item.description: Dr Sayed Talibi is told his conduct was "fundamentally incompatible" with being a doctor.

item.title: Pine nuts and goat's milk should get allergy labels, say experts
item.description: Warnings for some 'emerging' food allergens should be added to food packaging, researchers suggest.

item.title: Hospital pays out after bacteria-linked deaths
item.description: Nine families receive compensation after the outbreak linked to a Cambridge-based hospital.

item.title: Cut and bulk: Teenagers explain why they want to get ripped
item.description: The quest for brick-like abs has become serious business - even if you're only in Year 8.

item.title: Why the world is watching RFK's fight with US health agency
item.description: The US health secretary's plans could have a huge impact on health policy not just in the US, but across the globe.

item.title: The trade in US body parts that's completely legal - but ripe for exploitation
item.description: Human remains can mean profits. But there is an emotional debate about the ethics of the industry.

item.title: Sitting up straight isn't the only secret to good posture - here are three more tips
item.description: Here are Dr Xand's three suggestions on how to look after your back without turning into a statue.

item.title: Will Serena Williams's weight-loss admission help shed stigma of anti-obesity drugs?
item.description: Could her comments instil a new sense of confidence in those using the drugs and quieten the critics?

item.title: Lucy Letby's new expert supporters claim no babies were deliberately harmed. Who should we believe?
item.description: Barrister Mark McDonald claims to have the backing of a panel of world class experts who say there is no evidence any babies were deliberately harmed

item.title: Drinks that make you chill - do they really do what it says on the tin?
item.description: The wellness drinks industry is booming – but the big benefits they promise might be too good to be true.

item.title: A walk-in fishermen's clinic saved Tom from sepsis - and could transform the NHS
item.description: Tom Parker was treated in one of 70 harbour health clinics after breaking his fibula fishing at sea.

item.title: Could RFK Jr's move to pull mRNA vaccine funding be a huge miscalculation?
item.description: The US is withdrawing $500m for vaccines for diseases like flu and Covid. Health correspondent James Gallagher asks if it's the right call.

item.title: Why we need to talk about periods, breasts and injuries in women's sport
item.description: Understanding the pressure elite sport puts on women’s bodies is pushing athletes to new levels of excellence.

item.title: Students feel 'let down' by mental health support - but should it really be up to universities?
item.description: The number of students reporting mental health concerns is rising. But to what extent should the onus be on universities?

item.title: Babies made using three people's DNA are born free of hereditary disease
item.description: The method was pioneered by UK scientists to overcome devastating, often fatal inherited diseases.

item.title: NHS tracker - are hospital waiting times improving near you?
item.description: Use our interactive tracker to see if treatment waits are getting better at your local hospital.

item.title: Why are measles cases rising in the UK?
item.description: What are the symptoms of measles and how dangerous is the disease?

item.title: Alzheimer's has isolated us, says Fiona Phillips' husband
item.description: Martin Frizell has spoken of the social isolation faced by the couple since the former GMTV presenter was diagnosed.

item.title: Vaccine roll-outs cut deaths by 60% - study
item.description: The study looked at vaccines deployed during outbreaks of five deadly diseases.

item.title: South Africans fear spike in HIV infections as US aid cuts bite
item.description: South Africa has been at the forefront of the successful battle to halt the spread of HIV/Aids - until now.

item.title: Is RFK Jr's divisive plan to Make America Healthy Again fearmongering - or revolutionary?
item.description: The most powerful public health official in the US is reviled by some medics - but even some of his critics accept that he is bringing drive to healthcare areas that have long been neglected

item.title: How is your hospital doing as NHS battles to bring down waiting times?
item.description: Use our interactive tracker to see if treatment waits are getting better at your local hospital

item.title: Emma is doing something she swore she never would - buying her kids vapes
item.description: One month on from the disposable vape ban, one mum says it has had little impact on her children's nicotine consumption.

item.title: What is chickenpox and how can I get my child vaccinated?
item.description: The NHS in England and Wales will start offering the MMRV vaccine to young children from January 2026.

item.title: The teenage caffeine pouch trend troubling US experts
item.description: Some social media influencers are pushing products to young gym-goers and students, health experts warn.

item.title: Sleep, exercise, hydrate - do we really need to stick to recommended daily doses?
item.description: As a study casts doubt on the daily steps maxim, we take a look at some other health benchmarks we’re often told to strive for.

item.title: Is the most expensive lip balm always the best?
item.description: Do you need to spend more to get the best for your chapped lips?

item.title: Ketamine helped me escape my negative thoughts - then it nearly killed me
item.description: Young people are taking dangerous amounts of ket because it's cheap, easily available and helps them "disconnect", experts say.

item.title: The English neighbourhood that claims to hold the secret to fixing the NHS
item.description: With public satisfaction in the NHS just 21%, one area has a plan to shake up its services that could reduce GP waiting lists, as well as unblock hospital beds - but can it really work nationwide?

item.title: How does the disposable vape ban work, and how harmful is vaping?
item.description: The disposable vape ban is designed to reduce environmental damage and protect children's health.

item.title: Labour's plan for benefits throws up a bigger dilemma
item.description: The debate has sparked a wider dilemma about the broader purpose of welfare

item.title: First place in British Isles set to approve right to die
item.description: Laws in the Isle of Man to let terminally ill adults end their own lives are in the last stages of debate.

item.title: Generation K: The disturbing rise of ketamine abuse among young people
item.description: Increasing numbers of young people are using the drug, experts say. The health impacts can be catastrophic.

item.title: Assisted dying bill: What is in proposed law?
item.description: The proposed law would allow some terminally ill adults to end their own lives. But there are requirements.

item.title: 'My first cervical screening was over before I knew it'
item.description: The BBC speaks to six people about their first cervical screening, and what they wish they'd known beforehand.

item.title: Is the system letting down people who were harmed by Covid vaccines?
item.description: People affected by rare blood clots say they feel they have been airbrushed out of the pandemic.

item.title: How will weight-loss drugs change our relationship with food?
item.description: The rise of these treatments has major implications for how we think about obesity, says James Gallagher.

item.title: NHS needs better plan around weight loss jabs, warn experts
item.description: Experts call for an urgent review of obesity treatment services amid booming demand for weight loss jabs.

item.title: How many of us will end up being diagnosed with ADHD?
item.description: Experts suggest that the number of people with ADHD is actually going to remain steady.

item.title: The junior doctors' strikes may be over. But is trouble ahead?
item.description: The end of the pay dispute sounded too good to be true. And now some are wondering if it might be.

item.title: Union and government to restart talks on ending doctor dispute
item.description: BMA says there is window of opportunity in coming weeks to reach a settlement after 12 strikes.

item.title: Doctors' union agrees to resume talks with Streeting
item.description: But the health secretary says he will not negotiate on pay, adding that the union has lost goodwill with their five-day walkout.

item.title: The doctor strike has ended - what comes next?
item.description: With doctors returning to work after five-day walkout, is there an opportunity for talks to re-start?

item.title: Why did resident doctors strike and what are they paid?
item.description: Resident doctors in England went on strike over pay for five days at the end of July 2025.

item.title: Covid care home policy was 'least worst decision' - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary Matt Hancock denied claims the government's attempt to throw a protective ring around care homes in early 2020 was empty rhetoric.

item.title: Covid inquiry hears of 'generational slaughter'
item.description: Relatives of care home residents tell the Covid inquiry they will never get over how their loved ones died.

item.title: Covid inquiry to look at impact on care services
item.description: The Covid inquiry will examine the impact of the pandemic on care services, starting on Monday.

item.title: The Covid Inquiry Podcast: 'I wasn't the decision maker'
item.description: The Inquiry hears from the lead of the test and trace unit

item.title: Cash to isolate 'would have cut Covid deaths'
item.description: Baroness Dido Harding tells Covid inquiry Rishi Sunak blocked higher support payments.

item.title: Johnson wanted tighter Covid rules, inquiry hears
item.description: In his diaries, Lord Vallance wrote that ex-PM thought rules were not ruthless enough.

item.title: Hancock criticises 'wholly naive' Covid inquiry
item.description: The former health secretary was giving evidence about medical equipment deals during the pandemic.

item.title: Mone accuses Covid inquiry of 'cover-up'
item.description: She says husband Doug Barrowman and her are targets of a "politically motivated witch hunt".

item.title: Michael Gove denies trying to circumvent Dyson ventilator checks
item.description: Former cabinet minister says it would be ludicrous to suggest he tried to shortcut safety checks in the pandemic.

item.title: Michelle Mone-linked PPE firm evidence to be heard in private
item.description: Covid inquiry says hearings into the firm, led by Michelle Mone's husband, must be held in closed session.

item.title: Large UK-wide pandemic preparedness tests planned this year
item.description: The stress test will involve thousands of people to help the UK prepare for potential future threats.

item.title: Families failed by Covid jabs tell inquiry of pain
item.description: They said there was no support after the death and harm suffered by their loved ones.

item.title: NHS hours from PPE running out in Covid - Hancock
item.description: Former health secretary tells inquiry some healthcare settings did run out - "and it was awful".

item.title: Covid inquiry told Treasury blocked NHS bed request
item.description: NHS England chief executive Amanda Pritchard says the decision, in July 2020, was very disappointing.

item.title: Covid inquiry told top NHS doctor was terrified
item.description: Sir Stephen Powis says points-based tool was drawn up should need to prioritise patients have arisen.

item.title: How close were hospitals to collapse in Covid?
item.description: The Covid inquiry restarts its live hearings this week, after senior staff in the NHS revealed just how close some hospitals were to collapse

item.title: Covid inquiry told of trust do-not-resuscitate rule
item.description: Patients' families were “horrified but not surprised” when told the blanket policy had been in place.

item.title: We were not treated as parents, Covid inquiry told
item.description: Mum of premature twins says rigid restrictions on birthing wards during Covid were traumatic.

item.title: Calls to include menopause support in cancer care
item.description: A survey shows that 90% people say they are not given plans to help manage menopause.

item.title: Let's have a conversation about periods
item.description: Three teenage girls talk to 5 Live about the importance of safe and open conversations on topics such as hormones, periods and mental health.

item.title: Hospital opens room for miscarriage support
item.description: The space will provide "compassionate care during a profoundly difficult time", says a ward sister.

item.title: Woman loses faith in hospital after miscarriage
item.description: Emma Simmonds says she will never return to the hospital, this week rated England's worst.

item.title: Women's healthcare chronically underfunded, says Melinda French Gates
item.description: The billionaire philanthropist is donating $50m to research the issue, as part of a larger $1bn pledge.

item.title: One way Michael Rosen has coped with the death of his son
item.description: "You don’t die as a human being, you live on with others," Rosen told Saturday Live.

item.title: Gym with wellbeing focus welcomes lottery boost
item.description: The Soma Space offers combined strength training and psychotherapy, and prospective clients can be referred.

item.title: Wellbeing walking maps to encourage green travel
item.description: The illustrated walking maps guide people along four car-free routes in and around Tewkesbury.

item.title: Art charity 'buzzing' about opening of new £75m campus
item.description: Art Shape works with the NHS to deliver creative courses as prescriptions.

item.title: How a 'seated salsa' can help your lower back
item.description: It's hard to tone your lower back muscles, but this handy exercise can help.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Cystic fibrosis care, AI in cancer screening & science of run clubs.

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: Shingles vaccine to reduce dementia risk? Antibiotic resistant gonorrhoea & tech trousers

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: We investigate the safety of melatonin as a sleep aid, and should you eat your placenta?

item.title: Inside Health
item.description: We try to figure out why drug deaths are at an all-time high - and what can be done.

item.title: A soft play designed for autistic kids
item.description: The play area also has a calming room for children to relax in.

item.title: How gaming can be good for your mental health
item.description: Psychologist and gaming expert Nick Ballou has five ways how gaming can boost your mental health and wellbeing.

item.title: Let's have a conversation about periods
item.description: Three teenage girls talk to 5 Live about the importance of safe and open conversations on topics such as hormones, periods and mental health.

item.title: Why you might not need that magnesium supplement...
item.description: Drs Chris and Xand sit down with Professor Stella Volpe, the Head of the department of Nutrition, Food and Exercise at Virginia Tech in the US.

item.title: I quit my job to run a silent disco exercise group
item.description: The Silent Steppers began in 2024 to promote physical and mental wellbeing.
